part.title: Accidentals
part.para: Accidental signs are marks placed before a notehead to indicate that the pitch of the note should be altered. At level 1 you should know about three signs: the 'sharp', the 'flat' and the 'natural':

score.music: (score (vers 1.6) (defineStyle ''Style0'' (font ''Times New Roman'' 10pt normal) (color #000000)) (instrument (staves 1) (staff 1 (staffType regular)(staffLines 5)(staffSpacing 180.00)(staffDistance 2000.00)(lineThickness 15.00)) (infoMIDI 0 0) (musicData (clef G) (spacer 0 (text _''sharp'' (style ''Style0'') dx:34.0 dy:78.0) ) (n +g4 q v1) (n +c5 q v1) (barline double) (spacer 0 (text _''flat'' (style ''Style0'') dx:23.0 dy:78.0) ) (n -g4 q v1) (n -c5 q v1) (barline double) (spacer 0 (text _''natural'' (style ''Style0'') dx:24.0 dy:78.0) ) (n =g4 q v1) (n =c5 q v1) (barline end) )))

part.para: A sharp sign raises the pitch of a note by half a step (one semitone). A flat sign lowers the pitch of a note half a step (one semitone). A natural sign cancels the effect of a flat or a sharp.

An accidental sign alters not only the pitch of the note that it is attached to, but also the pitch of any subsequent occurrence of the same note in the same measure. Notes with the same pitch name, but in a higher or lower octave are not affected. The effect of the accidental ends at the end of the measure, so notes in the next measure will not be altered, except those tied to one in the previous measure.

part.title: Key signature
part.para: If, for example, a piece of music is written based on the D major scale, all F and C notes will have sharp signs placed before them. For example (play it):

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4) (n d4 q)(n e4 q)(barline simple) (n +f4 q)(n g4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n b4 q)(barline simple) (n +c5 q)(n d5 q)(barline simple) (n d4 q)(n +f4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n d5 q)(barline end) )))

part.para: Having to write accidentals always in the same notes can be annoying. To make the writing process easier, instead of writing sharp signs before all F and C notes, the accidentals can be written at the beginning of the staff, immediately after the clef sign. These accidentals affect the whole score and are named the 'key signature'. They apply to all relevant notes in every octave. As a consequence, it is no longer needed to place accidental signs in front of each note. So, the previous score can also be written as follows:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key D) (time 2 4) (spacer 20) (n d4 q)(n e4 q)(barline simple) (n f4 q)(n g4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n b4 q)(barline simple) (n c5 q)(n d5 q)(barline simple) (n d4 q)(n f4 q)(barline simple) (n a4 q)(n d5 q) (spacer 20) (barline end) )))

part.para: Note that the sharp for the F note is placed on the 5th line but it affects all F notes, independently of the octave.

The key signature, apart of simplifying the notation, gives information about the 'tonality' of the composition, roughly speaking, which scale is used to build a piece of music. The key signature must be written on every music line, placed immediately after the clef sign.
The accidentals on the key signature are named 'proper accidentals' whereas those added in addition to individual notes are named 'chromatic accidentals'.
